repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Second Mining Development
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact is substantial. Several lessons are drawn
            specifically from the project as follows. Creating an
            enabling environment, with responsive institutions to
            interface with the private sector is not only important, but
            it enabled significant contributions to the country in terms
            of mining exploration, and development. Moreover, the
            integrated approach to sector reform, outlines the
            applicability of the project and its components, as to the
            development of mining rights, and environmental management
            capacity, including the success of a well-defined
            coordination between the federal, and provincial
            implementing units, which established strong leadership, and
            active participation at the provincial level, providing a
            decisive stability factor. It is important to note the
            usefulness of the geodetic, and environmental data
            infrastructure, particularly for infrastructure, e.g. roads
            construction, national hazards mitigation measures, and land
            use planning. Nonetheless, sustainability of some of the
            project's institutional achievement might be
            jeopardized by the adverse macroeconomic situation of the
            country. However, core administrative functions are, as a
            rule, sustainable after closure of the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Second Mining Development
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main purpose of the Second Mining
            Development Technical Assistance Project is to develop and
            support the Federal and provincial governments' policy,
            regulatory and institutional reforms which encourage the
            environmentally sound expansion of private investment in
            mining. There are five components in this project. 1)
            Institutional framework development will include
            reorganization and staffing of key administrative units,
            setting-up of efficient work procedures, and training of
            staff in the public mining agencies of the 17 provinces this
            project concentrates on. 2) Mining cadastre and registry
            system will improve the reference mining geodetic network,
            introduce unified registering procedures and clear up
            backlog of pending concession applications. 3) Environmental
            management will carry out environmental and socio-economic
            baseline studies in selected mining districts. 4) Unified
            mining information system will strengthen the information
            management units in the 17 provinces and provide hardware
            and software. 5) Project coordination will monitor,
            supervise, and provide management control for all components
            and for the overall project.

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Second Mining Development
            Technical Assistance Project (PASMA II) : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the Second Mining Development Technical Assistance Project
            (PASMA II), expanding PASMA I by developing and implementing
            an institutional framework for environmental management of
            the mining sector applicable to the entire country. The
            mining of metallic minerals generates solid waste, some of
            it hazardous, and problems with water, soil, and air
            contamination; and it poses risks for flora and fauna and
            for people's health and safety. In arid and semiarid
            zones where water is already scarce and access to
            underground water is expensive, the water supply is further
            taxed. Where most of the mining areas are located upriver
            from the agricultural areas, surface and underground waters
            are affected. Effective waste disposal is important to
            prevent tons of residue waste from drying up and being
            widely dispersed by frequent, strong winds. Non-metal mining
            may produce air pollution, excessive noise, and vibrations
            when this activity is located near population centers.
            Abandoned caves from excavations can become flooded and in
            summertime be used as makeshift spas/"seaside
            resorts," which has led to human fatalities. Untreated
            byproducts from carbon processing muddy rivers. The report
            identifies the need to build public services infrastructure
            including health and recreational facilities to mitigate
            impacts on indigenous populations and other socially
            vulnerable groups. The Annexes outline specific mitigations
            for each project stage.
